description: On 17 March 2020 the President of the Republic of Equatorial Guinea sends a "message of alert" in which he states that "the particular situation in Equatorial Guinea is very worrying for the population, and it should be considered a State of Emergency".

Equatorial Guinea declares a Health State of Alarm for 30 days starting on 31 March 2020. "The Public Health State of Alarm declared in the previous article will be in force for THIRTY (30) DAYS, which may be extended depending on the evolution and development of the pandemic." UPDATE: The country officially declares the Health State of Alarm.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On 17 March 2020 the President of the Republic of Equatorial Guinea sends a "message of alert" in which he states that "the particular situation in Equatorial Guinea is very worrying for the population, and it should be considered a State of Emergency". State of Emergency extended May 1, 2020 through May 15, 2020. UPDATE: On April 29, 2020, authorities in Equatorial Guinea announced the extension of the state of emergency for two weeks beginning May 1 through at least May 15. The declaration grants powers for the government to impose restrictions to prevent the spread of coronavirus disease (COVID-19).
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On 17 March 2020 the President of the Republic of Equatorial Guinea sends a "message of alert" in which he states that "the particular situation in Equatorial Guinea is very worrying for the population, and it should be considered a State of Emergency". The State of Emergency was extended starting May 15, 2020 and continuing until May 31, 2020. UPDATE: On May 15, 2020, authorities in Equatorial Guinea have extended the state of emergency through at least May 31 to curb the spread of coronavirus disease (COVID-19). Authorities have stated that the extension will allow for the arrival of more medical material and equipment at under-resourced hospitals while controlling the spread of COVID-19.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: All international flights in Equatorial Guinea were cancelled starting March 15th. Travellers from countries affected have to follow a 14-day quarantine. Domestic flights were cancelled in the following days.

description: On Feb 8, 2021, Equatorial Guinea announced flight restirctions to contain the second wave of the virus including limiting flights so that: "For National Companies, two flights abroad per week. For International Companies, one internal flight per week. National Companies are restricted to one internal flight per day."
type_sub_cat: Other External Border Restriction
target_geog_level: All countries

description: Equatorial Guinea has developed a protocole for travellers coming in from "high-risk country - one with more than 500 diagnosed cases". These are "are immediately placed in quarantine. If the identified subject presents the common symptoms of COVID-19, which are fever, cough and a sensation of a lack of air, they are moved to the Isolation Unit at Malabo Airport, where the test is carried out and biological samples are taken so that, in three hours, the laboratory can diagnose whether it is a case of coronavirus or not. If no symptoms are present, the subject is taken to Hotel Bami -10 minutes from Malabo Airport- and placed in quarantine for further testing. After two weeks under observation and a second negative test, the person may go home. The sick who are diagnosed are taken to Sampaka Hospital [...] for the treatment of the symptoms. Faced with a suspected case, the intervention team acts quickly in beginning the epidemiological control investigations. The positive samples are sent to a recognised World Health Organisation centre for quality control." UPDATE: This is rather a Health Monitoring policy. Also, a protocole has been developed regarding the treatment of travellers and the way quarentine for such travellers takes place.
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
Equatorial Guinea obliged, as of 15 March 2020, "all travellers from affected countries, both nationals and expatriates, presenting symptoms on arrival, must remain in quarantine for a period of fourteen days. Likewise those travellers not presenting symptoms of any nature must, in any event, remain in quarantine for the same period of time; and thus they may not leave the indicated place, except with [an] authorisation."
Travel restrictions were eased starting June 15, 2020 so that "all passengers coming from abroad will have to carry a certificate of negative diagnosis for the coronavirus through a PCR test, valid for a maximum of 48 hours." UPDATE: On June 13, 2020, Equatorial Guinea announced it would lessen travel restrictions starting June 15, 2020 and that "all passengers coming from abroad will have to carry a certificate of negative diagnosis for the coronavirus through a PCR test, valid for a maximum of 48 hours."
target_geog_level: All countries

description: Equatorial Guinea adopts a decree "mobilising economic and material resources in order to combat the spread of the Coronavirus Pandemic on the Republic of Equatorial Guinea" through the creation of a "CORONAVIRUS-19 NATIONAL EMERGENCY FUND". "The Government is contributing to the Fund with a subsidy of FIVE THOUSAND MILLION (5,000,000,000) Franco CFA" and accepts contributions from any other stakeholders, national and foreign, both in cash and in kind.
type_sub_cat: Unspecified Health Materials
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: "On Tuesday 4th February the Coronavirus Technical Committee went to Malabo International Airport to instruct the Ceiba Intercontinental crew on all the preventive measures to apply in the case of an abnormal or risky situation." One exercise carried out on board the Boeing 777 consisted in disinfection techniques. "This training action will take place in other places related to the handling of air, lad and sea transport issues, in compliance with the Government programme on the prevention and contention of possible cases of coronavirus in Equatorial Guinea."

description: Equatorial Guinea enforces, as of 31 March 2020, "the suspension, until 15th April, of the circulation of vehicles and persons between districts. In other words, all districts in the Continental Region are being placed in quarantine, prohibiting the circulation or flow of persons or vehicles from one district to another." UPDATE: The original limitations to movement within the country have been extended: "The suspension, until 15th April, of the circulation of vehicles and persons between districts. In other words, all districts in the Continental Region are being placed in quarantine, prohibiting the circulation or flow of persons or vehicles from one district to another."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On Dec 21, 2020, Equatorial Guinea announced that "The Presidency of the Republic at the proposal of the Prime Minister of the Government, has approved this Monday, December 21, decree No. 197/2020 dated December 21, which temporarily restricts the movement of people during the Christmas holidays and New Year’s Day to prevent the spread of the Coronavirus in the Republic of Equatorial Guinea. Said decree will be in force from December 23, 2020 to January 15, 2021."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On Dec 21, 2020, Equatorial Guinea announced that "The Presidency of the Republic at the proposal of the Prime Minister of the Government, has approved this Monday, December 21, decree No. 197/2020 dated December 21, which temporarily restricts the movement of people during the Christmas holidays and New Year’s Day to prevent the spread of the Coronavirus in the Republic of Equatorial Guinea. Said decree will be in force from December 23, 2020 to January 15, 2021." This decree was later extended to last until February 15, 2021. UPDATE: The original decree to restrict the movement of people was set to last until January 15, 2021, however it was extended to February 15, 2021.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Equatorial Guinea rules the "temporary suspension of all religious celebrations. "The advice is to avoid gatherings of more than ten people at the same place.
Public transport via bus is prohibited.
Excluded from this concentration are restaurants and bars, provided they intensify cleaning and hygiene measures, and constantly disinfect floors, furniture and utensils. However, they may not hold or celebrate parties or large gatherings.
All parties, birthdays, baptisms, communions, marriages, consuetudinary matrimony, large traditional gatherings, wakes and funerals with a large gathering of people are prohibited, together with activities in leisure and games rooms, both day and night, fairs, discotheques, pubs, casinos, parks, public pools, etc."
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: As of 31 March 2020 in Equatorial Guinea "it is stressed that all stores selling clothes, various materials, supermarkets, general stores, pharmacies, hair salons, and stores selling electrical goods, electrical goods, household goods and utensils must remain open in a timetable that may not extend beyond 20:00h. [...] Restaurants and dining rooms which provide prepared food services must close at 21:00h." UPDATE: Equatorial Guine clarifies the regime of closure of shops.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: As of 31st of March (?) in Equatorial Guinea "In order to prevent possible contagion and the spread of the virus, there is a temporary suspension of all types of demonstration or gathering of over TEN (10) people in the same place, together with the celebration of parties, traditional weddings, wakes or funerals, burials, gaming rooms, beleles, parks, fairs and other similar events. Excluded from this concentration are restaurants, provided they apply personal distancing and cleaning and hygiene measures, and constantly disinfect floors, furniture and utensils. However, they may not hold or celebrate parties or large gatherings." UPDATE: Speficiations on the number of people that can gather.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: In Equatorial Guinea as part of the Health State of Alarm all collective transport is prohibited and taxis can only carry one person. UPDATE: Extension of the prohibition of all collective transport and limitation of travellers in taxis to 1.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On April 12, 2020, the "Equatorial Guinean government has declared the religious groups Universal Church of the Kingdom of God (UCKG) and Ministry of Liberation, Health and Prophecy illegal since last Sunday. The government announced this drastic decision because these organizations did not comply with the confinement measures decreed in the African country, due to the coronavirus crisis."
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Equatorial Guinea rules the "temporary suspension of all religious celebrations. "The advice is to avoid gatherings of more than ten people at the same place.
Public transport via bus is prohibited.
Excluded from this concentration are restaurants and bars, provided they intensify cleaning and hygiene measures, and constantly disinfect floors, furniture and utensils. However, they may not hold or celebrate parties or large gatherings.
All parties, birthdays, baptisms, communions, marriages, consuetudinary matrimony, large traditional gatherings, wakes and funerals with a large gathering of people are prohibited, together with activities in leisure and games rooms, both day and night, fairs, discotheques, pubs, casinos, parks, public pools, etc." Restrictions eased on June 15, 2020. UPDATE: The original policy was set to expire on April 13, 2020, however easing of restrictions did not occur until June 15, 2020
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On 21 Dec 2020, Equatorial Guinea announced "due to the "CORONAVIRUS-19" pandemic, the musical concerts by "T.N.O" and the free distribution of toys to children by H. E. NGUEMA OBIANG MANGUE, which has taken place to mark the traditional Christmas and New Year Festivities, have been cancelled for 2020, in order to maintain the precautionary measures adopted by the Government under Decree No. 107/2020, of 21st December, recommended by the Equatorial Guinea COVID-19 Response and Vigilance Technical Committee."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On Feb 8, 2021, Equatorial Guinea announced further restrictions on mass gatherings to curve the impact of the second wave of Covid-19 including "The celebration of weddings, baptisms, first communions and other sacraments which may involve the gathering of persons are suspended. Compliance with the preventive measures in places of Worship must occur both inside and outside the Temples.
The celebration of feast days, birthdays, weddings and other events that require the gathering of persons in communities are temporarily suspended.
Wakes will take place in strictly family environments, where the use of face masks and social distancing are obligatory."
type_sub_cat: Attendance at religious services restricted (e.g. mosque/church closings)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: "On Tuesday 4th February the Coronavirus Technical Committee went to Malabo International Airport to instruct the Ceiba Intercontinental crew on all the preventive measures to apply in the case of an abnormal or risky situation." One exercise carried out on board the Boeing 777 consisted in the use of masks and gloves and evacuation routes for exposed passengers. "This training action will take place in other places related to the handling of air, lad and sea transport issues, in compliance with the Government programme on the prevention and contention of possible cases of coronavirus in Equatorial Guinea."
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside Public transportation
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Equatorial Guinea has ruled that "the use of masks will be obligatory at all times" as of 15 March 2020.
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks in all public spaces/everywhere

description: "On March 23, 2020, the Government of Equatorial Guinea announced an order strengthening the precautionary measures and restrictions to reduce the spread of COVID-19.  These restrictions will be enforced by the forces of public order. Vehicles providing public transport are prohibited to carry more than (1) passenger.  Companies providing transport for employees should not exceed (2) passengers."
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on  private vehicles in public circulation
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: "H. E. Teodoro Nguema Obiang Mangue, who is leading the Policy Committee Charged with the Monitoring and Fight against the Coronavirus, called a meeting for 13th April, in which they strengthened the preventive measures against COVID-19." "The national executive will also provide free face masks to the population and will demand their obligatory use."
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks in all public spaces/everywhere
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: "Directors of clinics and pharmacies were called to a meeting on the morning of 14th April by the Minister for Health and Social Welfare, Salomón Nguema Owono, in order to reach an agreement on preventive measures and guidelines for the admission of patients." The minister asked not to allow entry to those not wearing face masks into hospitals.
type_sub_cat: Other Mask Wearing Policy
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Equatorial Guinea has ruled that "the use of masks will be obligatory at all times" as of 15 March 2020. On August 13, 2020, Equatorial Guinea government announced that masks continue to be mandatory in all public spaces and "all those not wearing face masks correctly will be held liable at the nearest Police Station" and there will be fines for non-compliance. UPDATE: The original policy was updated to include stricter enforcement for individuals not wearing masks in public spaces.
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks in all public spaces/everywhere
type_text: The policy makes it mandatory to wear a mask.
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines
